{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3565881,"name":"Çağlar Ayyıldız","username":"Quix28","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/q/e9a140/{size}.png","created_at":"2025-03-23T08:46:15.654Z","cooked":"

I was a rookie this year but probably I will have to handle the wiring next year because our electrical person is leaving. I don’t have much knowledge about FRC wiring so I have some questions for next year. This year our team had 2 CAN busses and one of them was only containing swerve motors and pigeon and the other one was containing the rest of the motors and the cancoders. I was thinking why cancoders were on a different CAN bus even though they are so close to each other. The only reason I think for that is a limitation of device number for one CAN bus. Is there a something like that or was that a choice made by the electrical person of our team? Also is it possible to run the swerves without the cancoders. If the answer is yes, one more assumption I had is that even though the other CAN bus was damaged we could keep driving and play defense. That would be a great benefit and if it is a thing I will continue to do the same thing next year.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-03-23T08:46:15.654Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":182,"reads":236,"readers_count":235,"score":967.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":496583,"topic_slug":"is-there-a-can-bus-device-limit","display_username":"Çağlar Ayyıldız","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":67147,"hidden":false,"trust_level":1,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"post_url":"/t/is-there-a-can-bus-device-limit/496583/1","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":0,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true,"can_vote":false},{"id":3565882,"name":"Emre ","username":"DukeEmree","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/dukeemree/{size}/251833_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-23T09:04:02.440Z","cooked":"

CANivore(Idk there is another way to add extra canbus) increases device limit(because it reduces bus utilization), transfer speed and bandwith. Also if there is a problem on one CAN bus it does not affect the other CANbus. With CANivore, you can increase your signal speed so data is fresher. So with CANivore you can improve the odometry of the robot. Also my teammate said that wiring is very easy with CANivore.

CTR Electronics

CAN FD

CAN Bus in FIRST – a history lesson In preparation for the 2015 FRC season, CTR-Electronics and National Instruments worked together to provide the first integrated CAN bus interface to the FRC community. This became the roboRIO single DW CAN 2.0 bus...

Quix28:

Also is it possible to run the swerves without the cancoders.

Yes you can run swerve with built in motor encoders(I haven’t seen many people use this).

Quix28:

If the answer is yes, one more assumption I had is that even though the other CAN bus was damaged we could keep driving and play defense.

I don’t think it is possible.

Our team is running our cancoders on a canivore bus with our swerve motors and pigeon, and our other motors are on a separate one. We did this for what you described, to avoid losing drivetrain if an arm bus connection was lost. We haven’t had any issues with this being too much.

Two (or maybe three) years ago my team had some sort of supply issue if i remember correctly and ran swerve using only the built in motor controllers. It actually will work well for the entire duration of match so its not an issue to run it using only built in motor encoders (the only problem is we had to orient our wheels forward before the start of every match haha.)

Quix28:

is it possible to run the swerves without the cancoders.

Besides using the relative encoders in the brushless motors (assuming the wheels start in a known position), other, non-CAN absolute encoders can also be used.

CAN devices have IDs which must be unique on the bus they are connected to. Older versions of CAN limit IDs to 11 bits, so the maximum number of devices that can be on the bus is 2^11, or 2048. Newer versions of CAN have 29-bit addresses, limiting the maximum number of devices on the bus to five hundred thirty-six million, eight hundred seventy thousand, nine hundred and twelve.

Practically, the limit is from running out of bandwidth for devices to communicate, or having such a large number of devices, wires, or connectors that the bus stops working reliably.

AVHon:

Newer versions of CAN have 29-bit addresses,

FRC allocates much of this to things that are not user-defined, however, so if you use devices from the same manufacturer, you only get 6 bits (64) worth

With proper signal timings and whatnot, you’ll realistically be able to fit a maximum of 25-30 devices assuming you completely disable all unused status frames.

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":11,"updated_at":"2025-03-23T14:01:27.028Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":81,"readers_count":80,"score":36.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":496583,"topic_slug":"is-there-a-can-bus-device-limit","display_username":"","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":50684,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"6032 | QDash"},"post_url":"/t/is-there-a-can-bus-device-limit/496583/10","custom_user_title":"6032 | QDash","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":true},{"id":3566010,"name":"Allen Nuttle","username":"nuttle","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/nuttle/{size}/124105_2.png","created_at":"2025-03-23T15:05:52.328Z","cooked":"

If you are running CTRE (CANivore + CANcoder), you really want to put the CANcoders on the same bus as the motors (particularly the turning motors). For closed-loop control, the motors will see the CAN traffic from the CANcoders and can close the loop using this data. It’s not a great idea to omit the CANcoders, and putting them on a different bus isn’t going to help reliability.

Also, in this setup, balancing the two busses isn’t just a matter of putting half the things on one bus and half on the other – the two busses have different overall effective bandwidths, assuming you have all CTRE hardware on the CANivore bus (which is something you should try to do).
